stories.title: Making a ‘new N64 game’: hardware-first optimization, profiling, and the F3DEX3 bet
stories.summary: As RTYI grows beyond vanilla SM64 scale, Kaze repeatedly hits failures that only appear on real N64 hardware: obscure MIPS/ABI pitfalls, alignment/DMA issues, register clobbers, and sudden FPS collapses from specific camera angles. Over time he moves from one-off fixes (culling, sprite coins, math tweaks) to instrumentation—using Sauraen’s trace/profiler to learn the game is often “slow” because it’s idling/waiting. The long-running mystery of why F3DEX3 seemed slower in RTYI becomes a months-long investigation that ends with microcode counter work and renewed confidence that F3DEX3 is the ceiling-raiser for the whole project.
stories.narrative_value: This is the documentary’s central engine: ambition colliding with physical limits, then a mindset shift from guesswork to measurement. It’s also where the project becomes bigger than “a ROM hack”—they’re effectively doing platform engineering—while naturally bringing in collaborators and downstream consequences for art, animation, and music budgets.
stories.challenge: RTYI must look and feel dramatically more modern than SM64 while still running correctly on real N64; emulator success can hide hardware-only crashes and misleading performance bottlenecks.
stories.process: Relentless console validation; targeted render optimizations; deep crash debugging (delay slots/register preservation); adopting a timeline profiler; and collaborative benchmarking/instrumentation to explain RTYI-specific F3DEX3 behavior.
stories.outcome: Kaze commits to F3DEX3 as the forward path with a concrete compatibility/TODO list; the team gains a profiler-driven optimization loop and a clearer mental model of what actually costs frame time.
stories.key_quote: It’s around 76% of the entire game—it’s just the game doing nothing at all.

stories.title: The hub world becomes the game: building a living, event-driven Yoshi’s Island (not a menu)
stories.summary: Kaze treats RTYI’s overworld as the entire Yoshi’s Island—something explorable, coherent, and reactive—so he intentionally delays it until enough courses exist to anchor pacing and geography. When the overworld push begins, the island quickly becomes a system: landmark foreshadowing (like the lighthouse), loopbacks, overworld-only quests/stars, and permanent world-state changes (fog lifting, reveals, rebuilds) triggered by player progress. A major milestone lands when you can run a full 360° around the island, shifting the remaining work to density, readability, and persistence under N64 constraints.
stories.narrative_value: This is the clearest articulation of RTYI’s ‘why’: not just more levels, but a unified world with cause-and-effect progression—something most ROM hacks don’t attempt. It also gives the film an inherently visual spine (before/after world changes, landmark payoffs) that can structure the entire feature.
stories.challenge: Make a massive, readable overworld on N64 that feels like a real island—without empty travel, arbitrary gating, or a portal-room vibe—and with robust save-flag/persistence logic.
stories.process: Geography-first planning; visible-but-reachable points of interest; progression gates as physical world events (not menus); auditing star counts so the hub has bespoke content; and pacing fixes (corridor shortening, warps/world map planning) while insisting on permanent change when events happen.
stories.outcome: A multi-biome island blueprint is proven and partially implemented; the core concept works, but it still needs content density, art consistency, and hardened persistence architecture to support all planned events.
stories.key_quote: The reason I leave the hub world for last is that I think the hub world is by far the most important part of the game.

stories.title: Building in Nintendo’s shadow: takedowns, demonetization, and a ‘free now, pivot later’ strategy
stories.summary: Kaze develops RTYI while treating Nintendo enforcement as a recurring, personal risk: past takedowns shape what he’s willing to publish, how he markets, and how he plans release timing. He rejects paid access models for the hack, explores safer “souvenir” options (like non-ROM physical merch), and commits to a free release with post-release open-sourcing—delaying anything that might leak unfinished content. In parallel, he outlines a contingency plan: if forced, strip Nintendo IP (Mario/Yoshis/enemies/assets) and convert the project into an original game that could survive outside Nintendo’s shadow.
stories.narrative_value: This adds external stakes and explains many otherwise-mysterious decisions (documentation avoidance, release pacing, monetization boundaries). It also reframes RTYI as both passion project and potential launchpad—engineering/design work robust enough to survive a forced identity change.
stories.challenge: Share and sustain a high-profile Mario-derived project without triggering immediate enforcement—while still paying collaborators and keeping the community engaged.
stories.process: Design onboarding into the game (less external tutorial content); avoid paywalled builds; separate merch from ROM distribution; plan release windows strategically; make copyright-resilient promotional materials; and maintain an explicit “original-IP conversion” roadmap if enforcement arrives.
stories.outcome: A coherent stance emerges: ship RTYI as a free, publicly accessible game; open-source later; promote cautiously; and keep a realistic escape hatch that preserves the work if Nintendo pressure spikes.
stories.key_quote: I will remove Mario from the game. And the Goombas. And the Yoshis. And I will make them my own characters.

stories.title: Kaze & Zeina: creative partnership, playtesting as truth, and life events shaping the schedule
stories.summary: Zeina becomes both a creative contributor and a reality check: watching her play exposes where Kaze’s instincts drift toward punishing design, prompting difficulty changes that prioritize empathy over pride. As Kaze expands technical capability (notably longer animations via streaming frames), Zeina’s animation/character work becomes a recurring dependency for NPCs, bosses, and comedic beats. Late in the timeline, they share a major personal milestone—a baby girl (Reyna)—turning the project’s schedule into something explicitly intertwined with their family life.
stories.narrative_value: This is the human spine of the film: the project isn’t just engineering bravado, it’s a marriage and a shared creative language under real-life constraints. It also gives a natural structure for a joint interview: how they calibrate tone, disagree, test ideas, and protect the ‘Yoshi’s Island spirit.’
stories.challenge: Keep momentum and creative alignment while scope grows and real-life responsibilities intensify; tune difficulty for real players rather than the developer’s skill level.
stories.process: On-stream playtests and observation-driven tuning; constant code/animation handoffs; tone-sensitive discussions (what feels too gross/too harsh); and open acknowledgement that parenthood changes timelines and priorities.
stories.outcome: A stronger player-empathy loop emerges and Zeina’s influence becomes visible in tone and presentation decisions; the project’s “final stretch” is now explicitly framed around family reality, not just technical ambition.
stories.key_quote: When I watch the player and it’s painful to watch them, I need to make it easier—and it was very painful to watch her.

stories.title: When movement changes, the whole game changes: custom collision, preserving identity, and player-trust compromises
stories.summary: Kaze makes a high-risk mid-project move: replace core SM64 step/collision logic to stop sticking and instability in more complex geometry. The result improves stability but reshapes iconic behaviors (like BLJ) and creates new emergent tech, forcing Kaze to decide what ‘counts’ as Mario 64 identity versus what must be curtailed to protect level design. In parallel, player feedback repeatedly forces compromises—restoring or reworking control changes when they violate trust, and shifting mandatory tutorials into optional mastery content.
stories.narrative_value: This is Kaze’s design ethos under pressure: modernize without turning the game into a different genre, and respect the player’s expectations even when it contradicts the developer’s ‘perfect’ vision. It’s also a rare ROM-hack story where speedrun culture, accessibility, and level-design integrity all collide in one system.
stories.challenge: Improve stability and feel without breaking the implicit contract of SM64 controls—or letting new tech trivialize platforming and onboarding.
stories.process: Rewrite collision/step logic; repeatedly tune/nerf movement options; evaluate emergent exploits and sequence breaks; react to backlash and surveys; implement hybrids (e.g., allowing a behavior but with tradeoffs); and codify rules against punitive or annoying mission structures.
stories.outcome: Movement is more stable and design guardrails are clearer; Kaze commits to a ‘player trust’ standard while still leaving room for expressive tech in controlled, readable ways.
stories.key_quote: By making more stable physics, it just so happened to remove BLJ. And I consider that a bad thing, actually.

stories.title: Course 11’s identity crisis: volcano → oil rig, then turning it into a playable workplace comedy
stories.summary: Course 11 starts as a volcano/construction idea, but Kaze realizes it reads visually monotone and lacks a distinctive identity. With Biobak’s input, he pivots hard to an offshore oil rig that manufactures Bowser’s airships, triggering a cascading redesign: traversal scale, visual readability (oil vs lava), and mission structure that still feels like Mario 64. Over many iterations it becomes a chain of sabotage setpieces and comedy polish (like wet-cement footprints that ‘remember’ Mario) under strict N64 performance constraints.
stories.narrative_value: A full creative arc with a clean turning point and lots of filmable ‘before/after.’ It’s also one of the strongest windows into Kaze/Biobak collaboration and Kaze’s core philosophy: clarity without hand-holding, and big setpieces that must still play like Mario 64 (not a scripted spectacle).
stories.challenge: After the theme pivot, the level risks being visually unclear, mechanically off-brand, and too linear—especially if it leans on one-off gimmicks or unclear objectives.
stories.process: Rapid prototyping of oil visuals; redesigning traversal scale (including multi-entrance underground); building layered hint systems and optional NPC guidance; implementing setpieces with performance-aware tricks; iterating via playtests and hardware benchmarking.
stories.outcome: Course 11 becomes a signature late-game level with bespoke mechanics and a proven pipeline for building large, themed spaces that still run and read well on N64.
stories.key_quote: All right, I guess we’re making it an oil rig.

stories.title: The 64MB wall: music quality vs cartridge reality (and Badub’s soundtrack becoming a production constraint)
stories.summary: Kaze realizes early that RTYI is racing toward a hard 64MB ceiling largely due to high-quality streamed music—at one point, the majority of the ROM is audio. That forces constant tradeoffs: streamed vs sequenced tracks, mono vs stereo, and even the possibility of dropping streamed songs for later courses. New trimming tooling (like STRM64) buys space back but creates new QA risk (loop points breaking), turning music into a persistent production budget rather than a solved creative layer.
stories.narrative_value: A universally understandable constraint story (kilobytes decide art) and Badub’s clearest entry point: composing isn’t just writing melodies, it’s navigating formats, memory, streaming stability, and how many songs the game can afford.
stories.challenge: Keep a modern, punchy soundtrack while staying under 64MB and maintaining stable playback/looping on real hardware.
stories.process: Track ROM budgets; evaluate per-track format compromises; adopt trimming tools; then audit loop behavior and cut/convert songs when necessary.
stories.outcome: Audio becomes a managed budget with evolving tooling; the team maintains the 64MB ethos while accepting ongoing compromise and verification work.
stories.key_quote: Currently, the ROM is 44.6 megabytes and 32.1 megabytes is music.

stories.title: Owning the sound: rewriting Mario 64’s audio engine and finally killing the crackle
stories.summary: Kaze spends weeks deep-reading and then heavily rewriting SM64’s audio engine, arguing it’s redundant, inefficient, and too limiting for RTYI’s scale. The refactor targets performance, code size, polyphony, and debuggability—accepting temporary instability as systems are replaced. A major payoff lands when a long-running crackle/buzz artifact that hurt perceived polish is finally eliminated (with only rare residual noise).
stories.narrative_value: A strong ‘under the hood’ arc with an audible before/after payoff, and a natural bridge to Badub’s perspective on what the composer needs versus what the engine can deliver. It reinforces the film’s central theme: they’re not just making content, they’re rebuilding a console game’s foundation to make a new one possible.
stories.challenge: The vanilla audio engine is a bottleneck and a source of hard-to-reproduce artifacts, limiting both quality and scale.
stories.process: Audit and simplify redundant logic; rewrite key subsystems; add better debugging visibility; stress-test across levels/hardware while chasing edge-case buzz/crackle.
stories.outcome: A substantially rewritten audio pipeline with a major polish win; remaining rare artifacts are tracked but the foundation is now controllable and extensible.
stories.key_quote: Now I understand the whole codebase—meaning it’s going to be very easy to debug any problems that may occur.

stories.title: The boss you don’t kill: reframing a corrupted Yoshi fight as healing an ally (and making it work technically)
stories.summary: While designing Course 15’s factory boss, Kaze realizes that ‘killing Yoshi’ feels morally wrong for a Return to Yoshi’s Island story. He pivots the fight into curing a corrupted Yoshi by destroying growths/weak points to restore it, then iterates on readability and N64-feasible tentacle collision to prevent jank and softlocks. When early visuals read as too disgusting, the corruption motif shifts from tumor-like growths to mushrooms to keep the tone shippable while preserving the premise.
stories.narrative_value: A rare collision of mechanics, tone, and morality that produces a memorable hook: saving the boss instead of defeating it. It’s also a clean example of RTYI’s dual nature—emotional intent and hardcore engineering—ideal for Kaze & Zeina to discuss together (and for Badub to frame musically as ‘healing’).
stories.challenge: Make a boss that fits Yoshi’s Island’s tone, reads clearly in SM64 camera constraints, and avoids technical jank/softlocks on N64.
stories.process: Redefine the win condition (heal/cure); prototype multi-cycle tentacle behavior; implement spline-based collision/hit detection; add strong telegraphs and safety behaviors (retracting, anti-trap logic); revise mutation visuals after feedback.
stories.outcome: The fight’s emotional identity is locked and a functional prototype exists; remaining work focuses on animation/polish/balance.
stories.key_quote: You end up saving him. All Yoshis are friends.

stories.title: Craft world ambition vs reality: inventing materials, then choosing simpler authenticity (paper airplane, staples, and readable performance)
stories.summary: Course 14 begins as a bold handmade diorama concept that pushes Kaze into ‘impossible on N64’ material experiments—fake shininess, CPU-generated shading tricks, and custom rules to sell styrofoam/paper/tape. As performance and stability issues emerge (overdraw, background Z buffering, brittleness), Kaze and Biobak pivot away from fragile tech toward simpler, more believable craft cues: paper edges, staples, gradients, and clear silhouettes. Kaze even folds a real paper airplane on stream to rebuild the in-game model correctly from physical reference.
stories.narrative_value: A satisfying reversal where the ‘coolest trick’ loses to taste, readability, and shippability. It spotlights Kaze’s hands-on obsession with authenticity and Biobak’s role as a performance-and-taste counterweight—while keeping N64 constraints tangible and visual.
stories.challenge: Sell a handcrafted illusion that holds up from any camera angle on N64, without expensive or brittle material tricks that are hard to author across many assets.
stories.process: Prototype advanced shading; test/profile on hardware; identify fillrate/overdraw risks; simplify the art language into repeatable craft cues; rebuild key props from real references to avoid uncanny “fake craft” vibes.
stories.outcome: Course 14 converges on a robust, expandable craft style that’s cheaper to render and less dependent on risky engine-side effects.
stories.key_quote: If I don't stay within the original limitations, am I not kind of cheating?

stories.title: Sustaining the project: paying collaborators, sponsor pressure, and the hidden emotional cost of leadership
stories.summary: As RTYI grows, Kaze begins paying collaborators (including Biobak) and talks candidly about the long-term need to compensate music work—while acknowledging monetization is legally fraught for a Nintendo-derived project. He also describes how sponsorships and outsourced editing stabilize YouTube revenue to support his family, even if it makes the channel feel more commercial. Underneath is a leadership tension: he’s reluctant to delegate because rejecting subpar work feels personally awful, so he keeps more work centralized than he’d like.
stories.narrative_value: This is the producer story behind the ROM hack: money, time, and relationships shape the game as much as code. It provides crucial interview ground for Biobak and Badub (what it means to be paid on a fan project) and reveals Kaze’s leadership style—high standards with real interpersonal burden.
stories.challenge: Fund and staff a long, high-polish project without burning out, damaging relationships, or creating legal/rights problems—especially around music and monetization.
stories.process: Reinvest donations into collaborators; explore what would be required legally for monetization; hire editing help and a sponsorship agency; set an informal collaboration policy driven by quality control and the emotional cost of revisions.
stories.outcome: RTYI continues with clearer financial scaffolding, but collaboration remains selective and time pressure continues to define pace and scope.
stories.key_quote: When you ask someone for help and then you tell them, actually, your help sucks... that always feels super bad for everyone involved.

stories.title: The unglamorous final mile: compatibility firefights, nondeterministic QA, and crashing from a 1KB shortfall
stories.summary: Even when content is ‘done,’ shipping repeatedly stalls on ecosystem fragility: launcher/core differences, flashcart quirks, and real-hardware edge cases that don’t match emulator behavior. Meanwhile, deep engine changes introduce new testing problems—like nondeterministic RNG behavior that breaks savestate-based reproduction—and regressions that can crash unrelated levels due to memory corruption. As art and overworld density increase, the project also starts failing by tiny margins (sometimes ~1KB of RAM during level load), forcing emergency pools, asset re-exports, and constant budget triage.
stories.narrative_value: This is the pressure-cooker story that explains why late-stage development looks like firefighting: compatibility and QA become existential, not optional polish. It also reinforces the film’s core theme—building near the metal means progress can be blocked by forces you don’t control (ecosystem) or can barely see (1KB).
stories.challenge: Make a highly custom N64 hack reliably playable across emulators/cores/launchers/flashcarts while maintaining reproducible QA and staying within razor-thin RAM/ROM budgets.
stories.process: Coordinate with maintainers on fixes; create diagnostic builds; cross-test on multiple environments; shift to isolated single-level test ROMs for cleaner feedback; debug RAM corruption; re-export/compress assets; reshuffle allocations into emergency pools to avoid fragmentation.
stories.outcome: Some blockers get fixed and a stricter QA/release workflow emerges, but compatibility and determinism remain ongoing risks that must be staged to avoid consuming all development time.
stories.key_quote: Every time I load a save state it’s a different one… so it’s not deterministic on the N64.
